segment.source: title: Composition effects
segment.target: title: Composition effects

segment.source: description: The effect APIs enable developers to customize how their UI is rendered.
segment.target: description: The effect APIs enable developers to customize how their UI is rendered.

segment.source: Composition effects
segment.target: Composition effects

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: The Windows.UI.Composition WinRT API allows Real-time effects to be applied to images and UI with animatable effect properties.
segment.target: The Windows.UI.Composition WinRT API allows Real-time effects to be applied to images and UI with animatable effect properties.

segment.source: In this overview, we’ll run through the functionality available that allows effects to be applied to a composition visual.
segment.target: In this overview, we’ll run through the functionality available that allows effects to be applied to a composition visual.

segment.source: To support Universal Windows Platform (UWP) consistency for developers describing effects in their applications, composition effects leverage Win2D’s IGraphicsEffect interface to use effect descriptions via the Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.Effects Namespace.
segment.target: To support Universal Windows Platform (UWP) consistency for developers describing effects in their applications, composition effects leverage Win2D’s IGraphicsEffect interface to use effect descriptions via the Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.Effects Namespace.

segment.source: Brush effects are used to paint areas of an application by applying effects to a set of existing images.
segment.target: Brush effects are used to paint areas of an application by applying effects to a set of existing images.

segment.source: Windows 10 composition effect APIs are focused on Sprite Visuals.
segment.target: Windows 10 composition effect APIs are focused on Sprite Visuals.

segment.source: The SpriteVisual allows for flexibility and interplay in color, image and effect creation.
segment.target: The SpriteVisual allows for flexibility and interplay in color, image and effect creation.

segment.source: The SpriteVisual is a composition visual type that can fill a 2D rectangle with a brush.
segment.target: The SpriteVisual is a composition visual type that can fill a 2D rectangle with a brush.

segment.source: The visual defines the bounds of the rectangle and the brush defines the pixels used to paint the rectangle.
segment.target: The visual defines the bounds of the rectangle and the brush defines the pixels used to paint the rectangle.

segment.source: Effect brushes are used on composition tree visuals whose content comes from the output of an effect graph.
segment.target: Effect brushes are used on composition tree visuals whose content comes from the output of an effect graph.

segment.source: Effects can reference existing surfaces/textures, but not the output of other composition trees.
segment.target: Effects can reference existing surfaces/textures, but not the output of other composition trees.

segment.target: Effect Features

segment.target: Effect Library

segment.target: Chaining Effects

segment.source: Effect Library
segment.target: Effect Library

segment.source: Currently composition supports the following effects:
segment.target: Currently composition supports the following effects:

segment.source: Effect
segment.target: Effect

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: 2D affine transform
segment.target: 2D affine transform

segment.source: Applies a 2D affine transform matrix to an image.
segment.target: Applies a 2D affine transform matrix to an image.

segment.source: We used this effect to animate alpha mask in our effect samples.
segment.target: We used this effect to animate alpha mask in our effect samples.

segment.source: Arithmetic composite
segment.target: Arithmetic composite

segment.source: Combines two images using a flexible equation.
segment.target: Combines two images using a flexible equation.

segment.source: We used arithmetic composite to create a crossfade effect in our samples.
segment.target: We used arithmetic composite to create a crossfade effect in our samples.

segment.source: Blend effect
segment.target: Blend effect

segment.source: Creates a blend effect that combines two images.
segment.target: Creates a blend effect that combines two images.

segment.source: Composition provides 21 of the 26 blend modes supported in Win2D.
segment.target: Composition provides 21 of the 26 blend modes supported in Win2D.

segment.source: Color source
segment.target: Color source

segment.source: Generates an image containing a solid color.
segment.target: Generates an image containing a solid color.

segment.source: Composite
segment.target: Composite

segment.source: Combines two images.
segment.target: Combines two images.

segment.source: Composition provides all 13 composite modes supported in Win2D.
segment.target: Composition provides all 13 composite modes supported in Win2D.

segment.source: Contrast
segment.target: Contrast

segment.source: Increases or decreases the contrast of an image.
segment.target: Increases or decreases the contrast of an image.

segment.source: Exposure
segment.target: Exposure

segment.source: Increases or decreases the exposure of an image.
segment.target: Increases or decreases the exposure of an image.

segment.source: Grayscale
segment.target: Grayscale

segment.source: Converts an image to monochromatic gray.
segment.target: Converts an image to monochromatic gray.

segment.source: Gamma transfer
segment.target: Gamma transfer

segment.source: Alters the colors of an image by applying a per-channel gamma transfer function.
segment.target: Alters the colors of an image by applying a per-channel gamma transfer function.

segment.source: Hue rotate
segment.target: Hue rotate

segment.source: Alters the color of an image by rotating its hue values.
segment.target: Alters the color of an image by rotating its hue values.

segment.source: Invert
segment.target: Invert

segment.source: Inverts the colors of an image.
segment.target: Inverts the colors of an image.

segment.source: Saturate
segment.target: Saturate

segment.source: Alters the saturation of an image.
segment.target: Alters the saturation of an image.

segment.source: Sepia
segment.target: Sepia

segment.source: Converts an image to sepia tones.
segment.target: Converts an image to sepia tones.

segment.source: Temperature and tint
segment.target: Temperature and tint

segment.source: Adjusts the temperature and/or tint of an image.
segment.target: Adjusts the temperature and/or tint of an image.

segment.source: See Win2D’s Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.Effects Namespace for more detailed information.
segment.target: See Win2D’s Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.Effects Namespace for more detailed information.

segment.source: Effects not supported in composition are noted as \[NoComposition\].
segment.target: Effects not supported in composition are noted as \[NoComposition\].

segment.source: Chaining Effects
segment.target: Chaining Effects

segment.source: Effects can be chained, allowing an application to simultaneously use multiple effects on an image.
segment.target: Effects can be chained, allowing an application to simultaneously use multiple effects on an image.

segment.source: Effect graphs can support multiple effects that can refer to one and other.
segment.target: Effect graphs can support multiple effects that can refer to one and other.

segment.source: When describing your effect, simply add an effect as input to your effect.
segment.target: When describing your effect, simply add an effect as input to your effect.

segment.source: The example above describes an arithmetic composite effect which has two inputs.
segment.target: The example above describes an arithmetic composite effect which has two inputs.

segment.source: The second input has a saturation effect with a .5 saturation property.
segment.target: The second input has a saturation effect with a .5 saturation property.

segment.source: Animation Support
segment.target: Animation Support

segment.source: Effect properties support animation, during effect compilation you can specify effect properties can be animated and which can be "baked in" as constants.
segment.target: Effect properties support animation, during effect compilation you can specify effect properties can be animated and which can be "baked in" as constants.

segment.source: The animatable properties are specified through strings of the form “effect name.property name”.
segment.target: The animatable properties are specified through strings of the form “effect name.property name”.

segment.source: These properties can be animated independently over multiple instantiations of the effect.
segment.target: These properties can be animated independently over multiple instantiations of the effect.

segment.source: Effect properties – Constant vs Animated
segment.target: Effect properties – Constant vs Animated

segment.source: During effect compilation you can specify effect properties as dynamic or as properties that are "baked in" as constants.
segment.target: During effect compilation you can specify effect properties as dynamic or as properties that are "baked in" as constants.

segment.source: The dynamic properties are specified through strings of the form “
segment.target: The dynamic properties are specified through strings of the form “

segment.source: The dynamic properties can be set to a specific value or can be animated using the composition animation system.
segment.target: The dynamic properties can be set to a specific value or can be animated using the composition animation system.

segment.source: When compiling the effect description above, you have the flexibility of either baking in saturation to be equal to 0.5 or making it dynamic and setting it dynamically or animating it.
segment.target: When compiling the effect description above, you have the flexibility of either baking in saturation to be equal to 0.5 or making it dynamic and setting it dynamically or animating it.

segment.source: Compiling an effect with saturation baked in:
segment.target: Compiling an effect with saturation baked in:

segment.source: Compiling an effect with dynamic saturation:
segment.target: Compiling an effect with dynamic saturation:

segment.source: The saturation property of the effect above can then be either set to a static value or animated using either Expression or ScalarKeyFrame animations.
segment.target: The saturation property of the effect above can then be either set to a static value or animated using either Expression or ScalarKeyFrame animations.

segment.source: You can create a ScalarKeyFrame that will be used to animate the Saturation property of an effect like this:
segment.target: You can create a ScalarKeyFrame that will be used to animate the Saturation property of an effect like this:

segment.source: Start the animation on the Saturation property of the effect like this:
segment.target: Start the animation on the Saturation property of the effect like this:

segment.source: See the Desaturation - Animation sample for effect properties animated with key frames and the AlphaMask sample for use of effects and expressions.
segment.target: See the Desaturation - Animation sample for effect properties animated with key frames and the AlphaMask sample for use of effects and expressions.

segment.source: Multiple Effect Instances with Independent Properties
segment.target: Multiple Effect Instances with Independent Properties

segment.source: By specifying that a parameter should be dynamic during effect compilation, the parameter can then be changed on a per-effect instance basis.
segment.target: By specifying that a parameter should be dynamic during effect compilation, the parameter can then be changed on a per-effect instance basis.

segment.source: This allows two Visuals to use the same effect but be rendered with different effect properties.
segment.target: This allows two Visuals to use the same effect but be rendered with different effect properties.

segment.source: See the ColorSource and Blend sample for more information.
segment.target: See the ColorSource and Blend sample for more information.

segment.source: Getting Started with Composition Effects
segment.target: Getting Started with Composition Effects

segment.source: This quick start tutorial shows you how to make use of some of the basic capabilities of effects.
segment.target: This quick start tutorial shows you how to make use of some of the basic capabilities of effects.

segment.source: Installing Visual Studio
segment.target: Installing Visual Studio

segment.source: If you don't have a supported version of Visual Studio installed, go to the Visual Studio Downloads page here.
segment.target: If you don't have a supported version of Visual Studio installed, go to the Visual Studio Downloads page here.

segment.source: Creating a new project
segment.target: Creating a new project

segment.source: Go to File->New->Project...
segment.target: Go to File->New->Project...

segment.source: Select 'Visual C#'
segment.target: Select 'Visual C#'

segment.source: Create a 'Blank App (Windows Universal)' (Visual Studio 2015)
segment.target: Create a 'Blank App (Windows Universal)' (Visual Studio 2015)

segment.source: Enter a project name of your choosing
segment.target: Enter a project name of your choosing

segment.source: Click 'OK'
segment.target: Click 'OK'

segment.source: Installing Win2D
segment.target: Installing Win2D

segment.source: Win2D is released as a Nuget.org package and needs to be installed before you can use effects.
segment.target: Win2D is released as a Nuget.org package and needs to be installed before you can use effects.

segment.source: There are two package versions, one for Windows 10 and one for Windows 8.1.
segment.target: There are two package versions, one for Windows 10 and one for Windows 8.1.

segment.source: For Composition effects you’ll use the Windows 10 version.
segment.target: For Composition effects you’ll use the Windows 10 version.

segment.source: Launch the NuGet Package Manager by going to Tools → NuGet Package Manager → Manage NuGet Packages for Solution.
segment.target: Launch the NuGet Package Manager by going to Tools → NuGet Package Manager → Manage NuGet Packages for Solution.

segment.source: Search for "Win2D" and select the appropriate package for your target version of Windows.
segment.target: Search for "Win2D" and select the appropriate package for your target version of Windows.

segment.source: Because Windows.UI.
segment.target: Because Windows.UI.

segment.source: Composition supports Windows 10 (not 8.1), select Win2D.uwp.
segment.target: Composition supports Windows 10 (not 8.1), select Win2D.uwp.

segment.source: Accept the license agreement
segment.target: Accept the license agreement

segment.source: Click 'Close'
segment.target: Click 'Close'

segment.source: In the next few steps we will use composition API’s to apply a saturation effect to this cat image which will remove all saturation.
segment.target: In the next few steps we will use composition API’s to apply a saturation effect to this cat image which will remove all saturation.

segment.source: In this model the effect is created and then applied to an image.
segment.target: In this model the effect is created and then applied to an image.

segment.target: See the Composition Visual Tree Sample on our GitHub for an example of how to set up Windows.UI.Composition Compositor, root ContainerVisual, and associate with the Core Window.

segment.source: Creating, Compiling and Applying Effects
segment.target: Creating, Compiling and Applying Effects

segment.source: 1.) Create the graphics effect
segment.target: 1.) Create the graphics effect

segment.source: 2.) Compile the effect and create effect brush
segment.target: 2.) Compile the effect and create effect brush

segment.source: 3.) Create a SpriteVIsual in the composition tree and apply the effect
segment.target: 3.) Create a SpriteVIsual in the composition tree and apply the effect

segment.source: 4.) Create your image source to load.
segment.target: 4.) Create your image source to load.

segment.source: 5.) Size and brush the surface on the SpriteVisual
segment.target: 5.) Size and brush the surface on the SpriteVisual

segment.source: 6.) Run your app – your results should be a desaturated cat:
segment.target: 6.) Run your app – your results should be a desaturated cat:
